docs.snippet: A week before the Oscars a British elf -- O.K., not an elf, but definitely British -- was crouched down, steam-cleaning a teal blue tufted slipper chair with a gracious curved back and deep, elegant buttons, shipped directly from the factory in Lo...
docs.lead_paragraph: A week before the Oscars a British elf -- O.K., not an elf, but definitely British -- was crouched down, steam-cleaning a teal blue tufted slipper chair with a gracious curved back and deep, elegant buttons, shipped directly from the factory in London. It was one of dozens of custom-made pieces from the atelier of George Smith, a leading English furniture designer, that were transforming a cavernous 1920s mansion, top left, in the Hollywood Hills into an intimate British-style club for a select group of guests in the days before the Academy Awards. The club is a weeklong outpost of the Soho House hotel-clubs of New York and London that opened on Monday. It includes a spa, lower right, and a paneled study with a 12-foot-long Victorian-style tufted leather couch, lower left, matched with spare '70s-inspired coffee tables from a local prop house. The dining room is draped in floor-to-ceiling midnight-blue fabric and has sea grass under foot. It leads out to a stone balcony, top right, whose ceiling is hung with artfully bunched white fabric and crystal chandeliers. Upstairs a billiards room has been redone with black wallpaper imprinted with Scottish thistles, while the sconces are antlers tipped with electric lights.
docs.abstract: Select group of guests is pampered at British-style club set up by SoHo House in Hollywood Hill for week running up to Academy Awards; photos (S)

headline.main: A Club That Will Barely Last Longer Than an Oscar Acceptance Speech

docs.snippet: "Crazy Love," the documentary that wants to become a feature film....
docs.lead_paragraph: "Who the hell wants to watch Josh Lucas blind Gwyneth Paltrow?" Bobby Zarem, the publicist, said to the Baguette after last night'screening of Dan Klores's "Crazy Love" at the Brant Park Hotel. The Baguette had suggested that the doc would make a good feature film.
docs.abstract: "Crazy Love," the documentary that wants to become a feature film.

docs.snippet: And this year's best picture, as chosen by the Bagger, is.......
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger will be locked in steerage on his way out to LA when you read this, and judging by the traffic updates from there, he better get credentialed up in a hurry. Weather-wise, the Bagger is leaving behind the proper cloth coat because it looks like there will be no freakish cold snap this time around.
docs.abstract: And this year's best picture, as chosen by the Bagger, is....

docs.snippet: The men of steel who count the ballots and stuff the envelopes....
docs.lead_paragraph: Reuters reports that the two men in charge of the counting the ballots and stuffing the most mysterious envelopes in the Western hemisphere don't divulge, ever, who came in second in the various categories: "That's something that we keep to ourselves, take to the grave, if you will," said Brad Oltmanns, who is conducting the tally with fellow PricewaterhouseCoopers executive Rick Rosas.
docs.abstract: The men of steel who count the ballots and stuff the envelopes.

docs.snippet: One Oscar-ologist sees a trend toward "Babel."...
docs.lead_paragraph: OscarWatch does not bury the lede when talking with Damien Bona, the author of "Inside Oscar. Turns out Mr. Bona is thinking "Babel" has the juice, which seems to be a trend of late.
docs.abstract: One Oscar-ologist sees a trend toward "Babel."
